case_title: COMMISSIONER OF INCOME-TAX vs RAM BILAS PURSHOTTAM DASS
complaint_summary: The dispute concerns whether the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal was justified in directing the Income-tax Officer to frame two separate assessments for two periods within the assessment year 1978-79.
investigation_summary: The Income-tax Officer framed a single assessment for the entire relevant previous year, rejecting the plea for separate assessments for two broken periods. The Commissioner of Income-tax (Appeals) and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal ruled that two assessments were required.
judgment_summary: The court held that the firm was dissolved upon the death of one of its two partners, resulting in succession rather than reconstitution. Consequently, separate assessments for the pre- and post-change periods were required under Section 188 of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
Decision_or_verdict: Question answered in favor of the assessee and against the Revenue.
legal_arguments: Section 187(1) and (2) of the Income Tax Act, 1961
Section 188 of the Income Tax Act, 1961
Section 42(c) of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932
Proviso to Section 187(2) of the Income Tax Act, 1961
citations: Dahi Laxmi Dal Factory v. ITO (1976) 103 ITR 517
CIT v. Kunj Behari Shyam Lal (1977) 109 ITR 154
CIT v. Seth Govindram Sugar Mills (1965) 57 ITR 510

precedents.case_name: Dahi Laxmi Dal Factory v. ITO
precedents.holding: Dissolution on death of a partner leads to succession under Section 188

precedents.case_name: CIT v. Kunj Behari Shyam Lal
precedents.holding: Death of a partner dissolves the firm; Section 188 applies

key_issues: Whether the firm was reconstituted or succeeded by another firm upon the death of a partner.
Applicability of Section 187 versus Section 188 of the Income Tax Act, 1961.

Whether the Appellate Tribunal was justified in upholding the order of the Commissioner of Income-tax (Appeals) directing the Income-tax Officer to frame two separate assessments for two periods within the same assessment year?

facts.event: Death of Prem Kumar on October 9, 1977
facts.returns_filed: Two separate returns for pre- and post-change periods

section_187.definition: Change in constitution of the firm
section_187.proviso: Firm dissolved on death of a partner is excluded
section_187.applicability: Not applicable due to dissolution of firm

section_188.definition: Succession of one firm by another
section_188.applicability: Applicable due to dissolution and succession

legal_terms.Succession: The process by which one firm takes over the business of another firm.
legal_terms.Reconstitution: Change in the constitution of a firm without dissolution.

words_and_phrases.Change in Constitution: Defined under Section 187(2) of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
words_and_phrases.Dissolution: Termination of a firm due to the death of a partner as per Section 42(c) of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the interpretation of Sections 187 and 188 of the Income Tax Act, 1961, and Section 42(c) of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932. The court ruled that the firm was dissolved upon the death of a partner, necessitating separate assessments for the pre- and post-change periods under Section 188.

judgment.reasoning: The firm was dissolved on the death of a partner, leading to succession under Section 188. Separate assessments for pre- and post-change periods were legally required.
judgment.costs_awarded: Rs. 250 in favor of the assessee
